bestBHT.bht: The Passover meal was already underway as Jesus and the Twelve reclined at the table, with Jesus lying back on the left side on the couch and his right hand free. This reclining posture signified a departure from the original requirement to eat standing, symbolizing their shift from a state of haste to one of rest. The meal took place at the regular time, between three o'clock in the afternoon and nine o'clock in the evening.

Albert Barnes: The lamb was killed 'between the evenings,' Exodus 12:6 (Hebrew) - that is between three o’clock, p. m., and nine in the evening.
The Jews reckoned two evenings - one from three o’clock p. m. to sunset, the other from sunset to the close of the first watch in the night, or nine o’clock p. m.
He sat down - At first the supper was eaten standing, with their loins girded and their staff in their hand, denoting the haste with which they were about to flee from Egypt.
Marvin Vincent: The imperfect tense ... denotes something in progress.
Introducing us to something which has been going on for some time.
John Calvin: Not to eat the passover, which they were bound to do standing, as travelers, when they are in haste, are wont to take food hastily, with shoes on their feet, and a staff in their hand."
I consider the meaning to be, that after having observed the solemn rite, he sat down at table to supper."
Accordingly, the Evangelists say, when the evening was come: for, at the commencement of the evening, they killed the lamb, and ate the flesh of it roasted.
Philip Schaff: He was sitting at meat, or, 'reclining at table.' The original requirement was, to eat the Passover standing (Exodus 12:11). The Jews altered this when they came to the land of promise and rest.
Both [Matthew and Luke] point to the regular time.
Archibald T. Robertson: He was reclining, lying back on the left side on the couch with the right hand free.
Jesus and the Twelve all reclined.
The paschal lamb had to be eaten up entirely.
John Gill: on the evenings of the passovers near the Minchah, a man might not eat עד שתחשך, 'until it was dark'".
the posture of the Jews, at the passover table especially, was not properly sitting, but reclining, or lying along on coaches".

even the poorest man in Israel may not eat until he 'lies along'...at the time of eating, the quantity of an olive, of unleavened bread, and at drinking of the four cups; but at the rest of eating and drinking, if he lies, lo! it is praiseworthy: but if not, there is no necessity.

bhtAttempts.bht: The events leading up to the Passover meal in Matthew 26:20 were already in progress, as denoted by the imperfect tense. Jesus and the Twelve reclined at the table to eat the Passover, with Jesus lying back on the left side on the couch with his right hand free. This posture of reclining was a departure from the original requirement to eat the Passover standing, symbolizing their transition from a state of haste to one of rest. The meal took place at the regular time, between three o'clock in the afternoon and nine o'clock in the evening.

The Passover meal at which Jesus and the Twelve reclined to eat was already in progress, according to the imperfect tense of the verb. They reclined on the left side of the couch with the right hand free, adhering to the Jewish tradition. This posture of reclining signaled their transition from a state of haste to that of rest. The meal took place at the regular time between midafternoon and late evening.

The Passover meal, which Jesus and the Twelve reclined to eat, was already underway, as indicated by the imperfect tense denoting something in progress. They reclined on the couch, with Jesus lying back on the left side, leaving his right hand free. This posture of reclining symbolized a departure from the requirement to eat standing, representing their shift from a state of haste to one of rest. The meal took place at the regular time, between three o'clock in the afternoon and nine o'clock in the evening.

This posture of reclining represented their transition from a state of haste to one of rest. The meal took place at the regular time, between three o'clock in the afternoon and nine o'clock in the evening.

This reclining posture signified a departure from the original requirement to eat standing, symbolizing their shift from a state of haste to one of rest.
